title: Just found out my gpu and processor are ass.
body:
This shit is worse than getting cheated on.

Now that I'm looking to build a gaming PC I learn so much. Never dropping 400 on a laptop that i'll be playing league on again.

RIP.

replies.body: yeah. a LAPTOP. They aren't meant to play anything unless you put some real money into them.

> [{quoted}](name=I Love Girlz,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-11-16T03:46:24.416+0000)
>
> yeah. a LAPTOP. They aren't meant to play anything unless you put some real money into them.

Plenty of 500-600$ laptops out there than can run ANY modern videogame on high graphics, if you are careful in what you look for.
For a desktop, 400$ barebones gaming build with 6gb ram, gtx750ti (more than you will ever need unless you plan on running two modern AAA games at once on ultra), 500gb seagate hdd or similar, i5 cpu or similar amd. 500-600$ tops, -100$ or more if you have monitor/kb/mouse/sound already, or dont need an optical drive.

> [{quoted}](name=MagicFlyingLlama,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-11-16T03:53:32.250+0000)
>
> Plenty of 500-600$ laptops out there than can run ANY modern videogame on high graphics, if you are careful in what you look for.
> For a desktop, 400$ barebones gaming build with 6gb ram, gtx750ti (more than you will ever need unless you plan on running two modern AAA games at once on ultra), 500gb seagate hdd or similar, i5 cpu or similar amd. 500-600$ tops, -100$ or more if you have monitor/kb/mouse/sound already, or dont need an optical drive.

modern games on high? Uh no. Intergraded graphics do not max anything besides maybe MW2.
Do you know what a GTX 750 ti is?

> [{quoted}](name=Avantel,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=0000000000000000,timestamp=2015-11-16T03:58:18.843+0000)
>
> Do you know what a GTX 750 ti is?

I was talking about the laptop. hence "intergraded graphics".

What the...?  Why do you keep saying intergraded?  Do you mean integrated?  If so, GTX750ti is a discrete graphics card and you can get discrete graphics in a laptop too...
http://i2.kym-cdn.com/entries/icons/original/000/010/692/19789999.jpg

> [{quoted}](name=Painted Celt,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-11-16T04:41:47.560+0000)
>
> What the...?  Why do you keep saying intergraded?  Do you mean integrated?  If so, GTX750ti is a discrete graphics card and you can get discrete graphics in a laptop too...
> http://i2.kym-cdn.com/entries/icons/original/000/010/692/19789999.jpg

You can only get discrete graphics in a laptop if will fit... Laptops have pretty unique mobos...wtf.

Well, the assumption that every laptop will necessarily have "intergraded" graphics is wrong.  

My laptop has both a discrete graphics card and an integrated chipset.  A switchable graphics utility app is used to configure which cases will use which graphics hardware.  For example, I can choose to flag specific programs to run on the discrete graphics card, or I can choose to only use the integrated chipset while in power-saving mode, etc.  By default, the switchable graphics utility will attempt to detect whether a program is graphics intensive (such as most modern games) and use the appropriate hardware.

Because I chose to get a laptop with a semi-decent discrete graphics card, I haven't had trouble running games despite that laptop now being around 6 years old.  The only issue I have had is that my laptop can get hot when the discrete graphics card is running for long periods of time.  The discrete graphics card also uses a lot of battery power, so I always plug the laptop in when playing a game.  

Anyway, the point is that you can get a laptop with discrete graphics, and there are plenty of laptops that are way more than powerful enough for casual gamers.

> [{quoted}](name=Painted Celt,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=00000000000000000000000000000001,timestamp=2015-11-16T23:04:41.115+0000)
>
> Well, the assumption that every laptop will necessarily have "intergraded" graphics is wrong.  
> 
> My laptop has both a discrete graphics card and an integrated chipset.  A switchable graphics utility app is used to configure which cases will use which graphics hardware.  For example, I can choose to flag specific programs to run on the discrete graphics card, or I can choose to only use the integrated chipset while in power-saving mode, etc.  By default, the switchable graphics utility will attempt to detect whether a program is graphics intensive (such as most modern games) and use the appropriate hardware.
> 
> Because I chose to get a laptop with a semi-decent discrete graphics card, I haven't had trouble running games despite that laptop now being around 6 years old.  The only issue I have had is that my laptop can get hot when the discrete graphics card is running for long periods of time.  The discrete graphics card also uses a lot of battery power, so I always plug the laptop in when playing a game.  
> 
> Anyway, the point is that you can get a laptop with discrete graphics, and there are plenty of laptops that are way more than powerful enough for casual gamers.

You can't just *add* a discrete graphics card to any laptop though.
There are separate GPUs for laptops. Different numbering system and not always as powerful, but that's because of size limitations

I even have an actual Graphics Card in mine, just upgraderd it too.

They are special cards and there are not much choices, but it does exist.

> [{quoted}](name=MagicFlyingLlama,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-11-16T03:53:32.250+0000)
>
> Plenty of 500-600$ laptops out there than can run ANY modern videogame on high graphics, if you are careful in what you look for.
> For a desktop, 400$ barebones gaming build with 6gb ram, gtx750ti (more than you will ever need unless you plan on running two modern AAA games at once on ultra), 500gb seagate hdd or similar, i5 cpu or similar amd. 500-600$ tops, -100$ or more if you have monitor/kb/mouse/sound already, or dont need an optical drive.

Would you reccommend the gtx750ti over an XFX radeon R7 260x? I know the gtx can work with intel and allow for streaming in the future when I decide to upgrade.

Just a word of warning about Radeon graphics cards, you may have a lot of trouble keeping the driver updated.  AMD's driver autodetect utility is garbage and the driver that it attempts to install for me is entirely incompatible with the actual graphics card that I have.  AMD is  infamous for being horrible about making sure proper drivers are actually available for their products.

A 1 TB HHD is only $50, so it's not worth getting anything less then that.
Don't really know how you would get 6 GB of ram..
But yeah, on my rig I have a i5 4590 and a a 750 ti, I usually get around 400 FPS on max settings on League, and it can run a game like Tera (pretty graphics intensive) perfectly fine.

I am going to be getting some upgrades for it this Christmas time. Going to be getting an aftermarket CPU cooler, another 8 GB of ram, a GTX 960, and a SSD. (plus some speakers and a HDMI cable)

> [{quoted}](name=I Love Girlz,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-11-16T03:46:24.416+0000)
>
> yeah. a LAPTOP. They aren't meant to play anything unless you put some real money into them.

Yeah this one was for school, and I'm just now learning how to build a PC, so lesson learned, though it is doing what I originally bought it for.

I have a GTX980 with 32 GB of ram (i have a friend who build pcs for a living, he hooked me up), and i spent around $850 total just on parts, he did the labor for free. This also includes some necessities such as wireless and 4 extra usb ports in the back.

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}} 

I don't like you right now

> [{quoted}](name=Avantel,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=BVUcsAI5,comment-id=00040000,timestamp=2015-11-16T06:16:49.235+0000)
>
> {{sticker:slayer-jinx-unamused}} 
> 
> I don't like you right now

Yea, alot of people say that to me.

"why 32 gb of ram!?"

Why not. Murica.

it's more so you got those parts less expensive then I could've
My PC parts (including monitor and OS) were around $920, and I don't have top of the line parts.

My whole setup is (around $1120):
NZXT s340 case
Core i5 4590
Gigabyte Z97-HD3 motherboard
GTX 750 ti
8 GB (2x4) HyperX ram
1 TB hard drive
Windows 7
21.5" 1920x1080 Acer monitor
Razer Blackwidow Classic
Razer Naga Classic

not like "graphics" really make a difference in league

the biggest difference seems to be line-age and shadows...not much for league

if you want a game to test your graphics on, try battlefield or Blacklight Retribution, though the latter is poorly optimized

I play league on lower to mid settings on a $300 laptop and so long as the connection is good, it works but sadly, I live in the middle of nowhere XD
as a tech, you get what you pay for bro

If you need any help with picking parts, I can answer some questions. Also Youtube channels like LinusTechTips (as well as the forum) and Austin Evans are a great help with the process.
The website [PCParts Picker](https://pcpartpicker.com/) can be a big help to make sure that all your parts work together, as well as get a united list of parts and prices
